query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 Ne l’ora che comincia i tristi lai 14 la rondinella presso a la mattina, 15 forse a memoria de’ suo’ primi guai,
16 e che la mente nostra, peregrina 17 più da la carne e men da’ pensier presa, 18 a le sue visïon quasi è divina,
19 in sogno mi parea veder sospesa 20 un’aguglia nel ciel con penne d’oro, 21 con l’ali aperte e a calare intesa;
22 ed esser mi parea là dove fuoro 23 abbandonati i suoi da Ganimede, 24 quando fu ratto al sommo consistoro.
query.result:
**English:**
13 At the hour when the sorrowful songs begin, 14 the swallow, near to morning, 15 perhaps in memory of her first sorrows,
16 and when our mind, a pilgrim, 17 less bound to the flesh and more taken by thoughts, 18 is almost divine in its visions,
19 in a dream I seemed to see suspended 20 an eagle in the sky with golden feathers, 21 with its wings spread and intent on descending;
22 and I seemed to be where Ganymede's companions were abandoned, 23 when he was snatched up to the highest council.
**Old English:**
13 On ðære tide ðe ða sarigean sangas onginnað, 14 ða swalewe neah ðære morgentiðe, 15 mægðan be ðæs sumeres gemynd,
16 and ðonne ure mod, ðæt wælgrim, 17 læs gebunden of ðære flæsce and mare gebunden of ðam ðancum, 18 bið neah godcund on his gesihðum,
19 on swefne me ðuhte ðæt ic gesawe 20 an erne on ðam lyfte mid gyldenum federum, 21 mid ðam wengum utrum and to gefeallanne georn;
22 and me ðuhte ðæt ic wære ðær ðær Ganymedes geferan wæron forlætene, 23 ða ða he wæs ahafen to ðam heahsetle.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Fra me pensava: ‘Forse questa fiede 26 pur qui per uso, e forse d’altro loco 27 disdegna di portarne suso in piede’.
query.result:
**English:**
25 Within myself I thought: ‘Perhaps this beast 26 is accustomed to staying here, and perhaps it disdains 27 to carry us up on its back from some other place’.
**Old English:**
25 Fram me selfum ic ðohte: ‘Þeos wildeor 26 bið her gewunod, and elles hwonan 27 forscunað me to beranne on his bæce’.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 Poi mi parea che, poi rotata un poco, 29 terribil come folgor discendesse, 30 e me rapisse suso infino al foco.
query.result:
**English:**
28 Then it seemed to me that, after she had turned a little, 29 she descended, terrible as lightning, 30 and snatched me up to the fire.
**Old English:**
28 ða ðuhte me ðæt, ða heo hwearf sumhwæt, 29 heo gefeoll ða swiðe swa ðunorleoma, 30 and ða genam heo me upp oð ðone fyr.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 Ivi parea che ella e io ardesse; 32 e sì lo ’ncendio imaginato cosse, 33 che convenne che ’l sonno si rompesse.
query.result:
**English:**
31 There it seemed that she and I were burning; 32 and so the imagined fire burned, 33 that it was necessary that my sleep be broken.
**Old English:**
31 Þær ðuhte ðæt heo and ic bryne; 32 and swa ðone ontendelican lig costede, 33 ðæt hit gebyrede ðæt ðone slæp abræce.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 Non altrimenti Achille si riscosse, 35 li occhi svegliati rivolgendo in giro 36 e non sappiendo là dove si fosse,
37 quando la madre da Chirón a Schiro 38 trafuggò lui dormendo in le sue braccia, 39 là onde poi li Greci il dipartiro;
40 che mi scoss’ io, sì come da la faccia 41 mi fuggì ’l sonno, e diventa’ ismorto, 42 come fa l’uom che, spaventato, agghiaccia.
query.result:
**English:**
34 Not otherwise did Achilles start up, 35 turning his awakened eyes around, 36 and not knowing where he was,
37 when his mother, from Chiron at Scyros, 38 carried him off sleeping in her arms, 39 from where the Greeks later took him away;
40 than I started up, as from my face 41 sleep fled, and I became pale, 42 as a man who, frightened, turns cold.
**Old English:**
34 Nis na oðerwisum Ahile ða aras, 35 ða wæccendlestan eagan ymb gewende, 36 ne nyste ða hwær he wære,
37 ða hine seo modor of Kirone æt Skiro 38 oferslependum on hire earmum bær, 39 ðanon hine siððan Grecas læddon;
40 ðonne ic ofslæpte, swa of minum wlite 41 slæp afleah, and ic bleoh gewearð, 42 swa ðone wer ðe forhted weorðeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 Dallato m’era solo il mio conforto, 44 e ’l sole er’ alto già più che due ore, 45 e ’l viso m’era a la marina torto.
query.result:
**English:**
43 By my side was only my comfort, 44 and the sun was already more than two hours high, 45 and my face was turned toward the sea.
**Old English:**
43 Be me wæs ða min willa geweorðen, 44 and ða sunne wæs ða ofer twægen tida, 45 and ic wæs ða on ðam sæ strande.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 Tu se’ omai al purgatorio giunto: 50 vedi là il balzo che ’l chiude dintorno; 51 vedi l’entrata là ’ve par digiunto.
query.result:
**English:**
49 You have now arrived at Purgatory: 50 see there the cliff that encloses it all around; 51 see the entrance there where it seems broken.
**Old English:**
49 Þu eart nu cumen to ðam clænsunge: 50 geseoh ðær ðone beorg ðe hine ymbeclyseð; 51 geseoh ðone ingang ðær he gedæled is.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 Dianzi, ne l’alba che procede al giorno, 53 quando l’anima tua dentro dormia, 54 sovra li fiori ond’ è là giù addorno
55 venne una donna, e disse: “I’ son Lucia; 56 lasciatemi pigliar costui che dorme; 57 sì l’agevolerò per la sua via”.
query.result:
**English:**
52 Just now, at the dawn that precedes the day, 53 when your soul was sleeping within, 54 over the flowers that adorn the place below,
55 a lady came and said: “I am Lucia; 56 let me take this sleeping man; 57 I will help him on his way.”
**Old English:**
52 Ða giet ða on ðære dægrædtid, 53 ða ðin sawl slep innan ðe, 54 ofer ða blostman ðe ðær beoð niðer geglengede,
55 com sum wif, and cwæð: “Ic eom Lucia; 56 læt me nimanne ðisne slependne wer; 57 ic hine læde ðurh ðisne weg.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 Sordel rimase e l’altre genti forme; 59 ella ti tolse, e come ’l dì fu chiaro, 60 sen venne suso; e io per le sue orme.
query.result:
**English:**
58 Sordello stayed behind, and the other noble forms; 59 she took you, and when it was daylight, 60 she came up; and I followed in her footsteps.
**Old English:**
58 Sordel wæs ðær læfd and ða oðre æðele hiw, 59 heo ðe genam, and ða hit dæg wæs leoht, 60 heo com up, and ic æfter hire sporum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Qui ti posò, ma pria mi dimostraro 62 li occhi suoi belli quella intrata aperta; 63 poi ella e ’l sonno ad una se n’andaro».
query.result:
**English:**
61 Here she placed me, but first her lovely eyes 62 showed me the open entrance; 63 then she and sleep departed together.
**Old English:**
61 Hēr hē mē gesette, ac ǣr his beorhte ēagan 62 ðā inngang openne æteowdon; 63 ðā hēo and slǣp tōgædere fōron.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 A guisa d’uom che ’n dubbio si raccerta 65 e che muta in conforto sua paura, 66 poi che la verità li è discoperta,
67 mi cambia’ io; e come sanza cura 68 vide me ’l duca mio, su per lo balzo 69 si mosse, e io di rietro inver’ l’altura.
query.result:
**English:**
64 Like a man who reassures himself in doubt 65 and changes his fear into comfort, 66 after the truth has been revealed to him,
67 so did I change; and as my guide saw me 68 without worry, he moved up the cliff, 69 and I followed him toward the heights.
**Old English:**
64 Swa swa mon ðe on tweon bþ gecearfad 65 and his ege to efnþe gewend hæfþ, 66 siþþan him soþ biþ geswutelod,
67 swa ic ða geweard; and swa min latteow me 68 geseah ungeorne, up ofer ðone beorg 69 he stop, and ic æfter in ða healþu.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 Lettor, tu vedi ben com’ io innalzo 71 la mia matera, e però con più arte 72 non ti maravigliar s’io la rincalzo.
query.result:
**English:**
70 Reader, you see well how I elevate 71 my subject matter, and therefore do not be surprised 72 if I reinforce it with more artistry.
**Old English:**
70 Lareow, ðu gesyhst wel hu ic upahefge 71 ða mine ðing, and forðy ne wundrige ðe 72 ðeah ic ða mid maran cræfte gefæstnige.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Noi ci appressammo, ed eravamo in parte 74 che là dove pareami prima rotto, 75 pur come un fesso che muro diparte,
76 vidi una porta, e tre gradi di sotto 77 per gire ad essa, di color diversi, 78 e un portier ch’ancor non facea motto.
query.result:
**English:**
73 We drew near, and were in a place 74 where, where it had seemed to me broken before, 75 just like a crack that divides a wall,
76 I saw a gate, and three steps below 77 to go to it, of different colors, 78 and a doorkeeper who still said nothing.
**Old English:**
73 We nealæhton, and wæron on ðære stowe 74 ðær me ðuhte ær ðæt brocen wære, 75 swylce hit wære an sceððe ðe weall todæleð,
76 ic geseah ðær ane duru, and ðreo ðremmas niðer 77 to ganganne ðærto, mislicra hiwa, 78 and ðone duruweard ðe ða gyt nænigu word ne mælde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 «Dite costinci: che volete voi?», 86 cominciò elli a dire, «ov’ è la scorta? 87 Guardate che ’l venir sù non vi nòi».
query.result:
**English:**
85 "Tell me from there: what do you want?", 86 he began to say, "where is your guide? 87 Beware that the ascent does not harm you".
**Old English:**
85 "Secgað me from ðanon: hwæt is eower willa?", 86 ongan he ða sprecan, "hwær is eower latteow? 87 Warniað ðæt ðe steapnes ne derie".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 «Donna del ciel, di queste cose accorta», 89 rispuose ’l mio maestro a lui, «pur dianzi 90 ne disse: “Andate là: quivi è la porta”».
query.result:
**English:**
88 "Lady of heaven, aware of these things," 89 my master replied to him, "just now 90 she said to us: 'Go there: there is the gate.'"
**Old English:**
88 "Frowe of heofenum, ðissa ðinga gleaw," 89 andswarode min lareow him, "ær ðisum 90 heo cwæð to us: 'Gað forð: ðær is ðæt geat.'"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 «Ed ella i passi vostri in bene avanzi», 92 ricominciò il cortese portinaio: 93 «Venite dunque a’ nostri gradi innanzi».
query.result:
**English:**
91 "And may she advance your steps for good," 92 the courteous gatekeeper began again, 93 "Come then before our steps."
**Old English:**
91 "And heo ða eowre foregonges in gode gefremme," 92 eft ongan ða gesæliga weard sprecan: 93 "Cumað nu to ure stæpe beforan."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 Là ne venimmo; e lo scaglion primaio 95 bianco marmo era sì pulito e terso, 96 ch’io mi specchiai in esso qual io paio.
query.result:
**English:**
94 There we came; and the first step 95 was of white marble so polished and smooth, 96 that I saw myself in it as I appear.
**Old English:**
94 Þær we comon; and se forma ærost 95 wæs of hwitum marman swa clæne and swa scearum, 96 ðæt ic me on ðam geseah swa ic ða gewuna.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 Era il secondo tinto più che perso, 98 d’una petrina ruvida e arsiccia, 99 crepata per lo lungo e per traverso.
query.result:
**English:**
97 The second was tinted more than purple, 98 of a rough and scorched stone, 99 cracked lengthwise and crosswise.
**Old English:**
97 Wæs se oder teint mare ðonne purpur, 98 of anre stanes ruh and adryslic, 99 tobrocen ðurh ða lengðe and ðurh ða brædu.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 Lo terzo, che di sopra s’ammassiccia, 101 porfido mi parea, sì fiammeggiante 102 come sangue che fuor di vena spiccia.
query.result:
**English:**
100 The third, which masses up above, 101 seemed to me to be porphyry, so flaming 102 like blood that spurts out of a vein.
**Old English:**
100 Se ðridda, ðe ðærof ufan amassicgað, 101 me ðuhte ðæt wære porfir, swa read 102 swa ðæt blod ðæt of ædre springeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 Sovra questo tenëa ambo le piante 104 l’angel di Dio sedendo in su la soglia 105 che mi sembiava pietra di diamante.
query.result:
**English:**
103 Upon this threshold the angel of God was sitting, 104 with both feet resting upon it, 105 and it seemed to me to be made of diamond.
**Old English:**
103 Uppon ðiss þreax ðæs Godes engel 104 sittende uppon ðære ðreschwold, 105 ðe me ðuhte ðe wære ðiamantes stan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 Per li tre gradi sù di buona voglia 107 mi trasse il duca mio, dicendo: «Chiedi 108 umilemente che ’l serrame scioglia».
query.result:
**English:**
106 Upward along the three steps with good will 107 my leader drew me, saying, "Ask humbly 108 that he unfasten the lock."
**Old English:**
106 Uppon ða ðreo stega mid godre willan 107 me lædde min heretoga, secgende: "Bidd ðu 108 eaðmodlice ðæt he ðone serran unslite."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Divoto mi gittai a’ santi piedi; 110 misericordia chiesi e ch’el m’aprisse, 111 ma tre volte nel petto pria mi diedi.
query.result:
**English:**
109 Devoutly I threw myself at the holy feet; 110 I asked for mercy and for him to open up to me, 111 but first I struck myself in the chest three times.
**Old English:**
109 Eadmodlice ic me wearp to ðam halgan fotum; 110 mildheortnesse ic bæd and ðæt he me geopenode, 111 ac ðrie siðan on ðam breostum ær ic me sealde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 Sette P ne la fronte mi descrisse 113 col punton de la spada, e «Fa che lavi, 114 quando se’ dentro, queste piaghe» disse.
query.result:
**English:**
112 Seven P's he inscribed on my forehead 113 with the point of his sword, and said, "Make sure you wash 114 these wounds when you are inside."
**Old English:**
112 Seofon P on minre sidan he awrat 113 mid ðæs sweordes ecge, and cwæð, "Loca ða, 114 ðonne ðu ðær inne sy, ðas wunda" cwæð he.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 Cenere, o terra che secca si cavi, 116 d’un color fora col suo vestimento; 117 e di sotto da quel trasse due chiavi.
query.result:
**English:**
115 Ashes, or earth dug up dry, 116 would be of one color with his raiment; 117 and from beneath it he drew forth two keys.
**Old English:**
115 Ascan, oððe eorðe ðe dreorig sie, 116 wære ðæs ilcan hiwes ðæs his hrægl wæs; 117 and of ðam he twægen teonum bræc.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 L’una era d’oro e l’altra era d’argento; 119 pria con la bianca e poscia con la gialla 120 fece a la porta sì, ch’i’ fu’ contento.
query.result:
**English:**
118 One was of gold and the other was of silver; 119 first with the white and then with the yellow 120 he did so to the gate that I was content.
**Old English:**
118 An wæs of golde and oðer wæs of seolfre; 119 ærst mid ðære hwitan and siððan mid ðære geolocan 120 he dyde ðære dura ðæt ic wæs bliðe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 «Quandunque l’una d’este chiavi falla, 122 che non si volga dritta per la toppa», 123 diss’ elli a noi, «non s’apre questa calla.
query.result:
**English:**
121 "Whenever one of these keys fails, 122 so that it does not turn straight in the lock," 123 he said to us, "this passage does not open.
**Old English:**
121 "Þonne hwilc ðæra ceaga gebreceð, 122 ðæt hit ne mæge ðurh ða toppe tihtan," 123 cwæð he to us, "ne bið þeos duru onlocen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Più cara è l’una; ma l’altra vuol troppa 125 d’arte e d’ingegno avanti che diserri, 126 perch’ ella è quella che ’l nodo digroppa.
query.result:
**English:**
124 One is dearer; but the other requires too much 125 of art and ingenuity before it opens, 126 because it is the one that ties the knot.
**Old English:**
124 Leofre is seo an; ac seo oðer wile 125 cræftes and gleawsccipes ær hit unluce, 126 forðæm heo is seo ðe ðone cnottan cnytt.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Da Pier le tegno; e dissemi ch’i’ erri 128 anzi ad aprir ch’a tenerla serrata, 129 pur che la gente a’ piedi mi s’atterri».
query.result:
**English:**
127 Then Peter made a sign to him, and said to me that I should open it rather than keep it closed, 128 provided that the people would fall down at my feet.
**Old English:**
127 ða Petrus him tæhte; and sæde me ðæt ic sceolde ða duru ontynan ðonne belocenre healdan, 128 ðurh ðæt ðæt folc to minum fotum afeolle.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 Poi pinse l’uscio a la porta sacrata, 131 dicendo: «Intrate; ma facciovi accorti 132 che di fuor torna chi ’n dietro si guata».
query.result:
**English:**
130 Then he pushed the door of the sacred gate, 131 saying: "Enter; but I warn you 132 that whoever looks back will be turned away."
**Old English:**
130 Þa he ðone duru ðære halgan geate 131 onsægdæ: "Gæð in; ac ic ðe secge 132 ðæt se bið awend ut of ðære duru 133 se ðe eft bið wended."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 E quando fuor ne’ cardini distorti 134 li spigoli di quella regge sacra, 135 che di metallo son sonanti e forti,
136 non rugghiò sì né si mostrò sì acra 137 Tarpëa, come tolto le fu il buono 138 Metello, per che poi rimase macra.
query.result:
**English:**
133 And when the pivots of that sacred portal, 134 which are of metal, sonorous and strong, 135 were forced out of their twisted hinges,
136 Tarpeia did not roar so loud or show herself so fierce 137 when the good Metellus was taken from her, 138 because of which she remained desolate.
**Old English:**
133 And ða ða ða cardines of ðam cyrnelhûse 134 ða wæron of metalle ða wæron swiðe hlûde and strange,
136 ne grymetode heo na swa ne heo ne æteowde heo na swa egeslice 137 Tarpëa ða ða ðe hire wæs ðæt gode benumen 138 Metellus ðurh ðæt heo ða wæs ðæs wæstmes berœfod.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 Io mi rivolsi attento al primo tuono, 140 e ‘Te Deum laudamus’ mi parea 141 udire in voce mista al dolce suono.
query.result:
**English:**
139 I turned attentively to the first thunderclap, 140 and it seemed to me that I heard 141 “Te Deum laudamus” mixed in with the sweet sound.
**Old English:**
139 Ic me wende geornlice to ðæm ærestan ðunorhlæste, 140 and ‘Te Deum laudamus’ me ðuhte 141 gehyran on stefne gemenged to ðæm swetan swæge.
